article_title: Season's first Affordable Care Act deadline is at hand
article_text:
Season's first Affordable Care Act deadline is at hand

Photo: BOB OWEN, Staff U.S. Department of Health and Human Services Secretary Sylvia...

Those who want to ensure they have health insurance coverage on Jan. 1 must sign up for a new plan or continue an existing one through the Affordable Care Act's exchange by Tuesday.

article_metadata.description: For a family, it will more than double from 2015, jumping to $2,085, or 2.5 percent of household income, whichever is greater.  Because many plans changed for 2016 and offerings by insurers are more limited in some plans, Burwell and other Health and Human Services officials urge those signing up to use available software to calculate premiums and out-of-pocket costs and to check to see if specific doctors are covered.  During her San Antonio stop, she answered questions about the controversy over the state's largest insurer, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Texas, dropping all its Preferred Provider Organization plans, which typically offer greater choice in doctors and hospitals and let customers go out of network.  In Houston, which is known for its top-tier medical services at the Texas Medical Center, the criticism has been sharp as some of the 88,000 in the area who lost PPO coverage say it has limited their ability to get complex medical care.  On Monday, Burwell said private insurance companies have seen a "reduction in demand" for PPO coverage and are responding to customer wishes.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam  and Peggy O'Hare
